references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.A89GAL01NAUS: Galbraith, D. A., R. J. Brooks, and M. E. Obbard. 1989. The influence of growth rate on age and body size at maturity in female snapping turtles (CHELYDRA SERPENTINA). Copeia 1989:896-904.
references.A94CON03NAUS: Congdon, J. D., A. E. Dunham, and R. C. van Loben Sels. 1994. Demographics of common snapping turtles (CHELYDRA SERPENTINA):implications for conservation and management of long-lived organisms. American Zoologist 34:397-408.
references.A88BRO01NAUS: Brooks, R. J., et al. 1988. Developing management guidelines for snapping turtles. Pages 174-179 in B88SZA01NA.
references.B72ERN01NAUS: Ernst, C. H., and R. W. Barbour. 1972. Turtles of the United States. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 347 pp.
references.A87CON01NAUS: Congdon, J. D., et al. 1987. Reproduction and nesting ecology of snapping turtles (CHELYDRA SERPENTINA) in southeastern Michigan. Herpetologica 43:39-54.
references.A95PET01NAUS: Pettit, K. E., C. A. Bishop, and R. J. Brooks. 1995. Home range and movements of the common snapping turtle, CHELYDRA SERPENTINA SERPENTINA, in a coastal wetland of Hamilton Harbour, Lake Ontario, Canada. Canadian Field-Naturalist 109:192-200.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.A91IVE04NAUS: Iverson, J. B. 1991. Patterns of survivorship in turtles (order Testudines). Canadian J. Zoology 69:385-391.
references.A94BRO01NAUS: Brown, G. P., and R. J. Brooks. 1994. Characteristics of and fidelity to hibernacula in a northern population of snapping turtles, CHELYDRA SERPENTINA. Copeia 1994:222-226.
references.B94ERN01NAUS: Ernst, C. H., R. W. Barbour, and J. E. Lovich. 1994. Turtles of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, D.C. xxxviii + 578 pp.

references.A89GAL03NAUS: Galbraith, D. A., and R. J. Brooks. 1989. Age estimates for snapping turtles. J. Wildl. Manage. 53:502-508.
references.B88GIB01NAUS: Gibbons, J. W., S. S. Novak, and C. H. Ernst. 1988. CHELYDRA SERPENTINA. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 420.1-420.4.
references.A87GAL01NAUS: Galbraith, D. A., M. W. Chandler, and R. J. Brooks. 1987. The fine structure of home ranges of male CHELYDRA SERPENTINA:are snapping turtles territiorial. Can. J. Zool. 65:2623-2629.

habitat_description:
The range of the common snapping turtle extends from southern Alberta across southern Canada to Nova Scotia, then south to the Gulf Coast and through Mexico and Central America into northern portions of South America. Gaps in the range occur in most of northern and central Mexico. The western expansion of this species’ range is the result of multiple introductions (Natureserve.org).

This benthic species is known to burrow in or using soil, decaying logs, and leaf litter. Nesting sites are located in soft soil or in muskrat houses found in open areas several hundred meters from a permanent water source (Congdon et al. 1987). The habitats occupied by this species include big river drainages, river mouths, tidal areas, low gradient streams, shallow and deep pools of water. Also, herbaceous wetland, forested wetland, scrub-shrub wetland, and temporary pools that occur in riparian zones (Natureserve.org).

This species is found in all types of freshwater habitats. In particular, snapping turtles are found in water bodies characterized by soft, muddy bottoms and abundant aquatic vegetation, or submerged decaying logs. They also occur in some brackish situations. Prolonged periods of inactivity are spend at the bottom of water bodies, but also a substantial amount of time is spent basking in areas nearby water (Brown and Brooks 1994; Herman et al. 1995; Natureserve.org). Hibernation also takes place at the bottom of water bodies, under submerged logs, under vegetation, under overhanging banks, muskrat tunnels/houses, and sometimes even in sites devoid of oxygen (Brown and Brooks 1994; Herman et al. 1995).
